title: Much more than just a minute
text:
You won’t be too surprised to hear that the answer from a legal perspective is yes and no.

A joint statement released recently by the Governance Institute of Australia and the Australian Institute of Company Directors (AICD) has set out to help boards with what a good set of minutes should and shouldn’t look like.

The key message is this: while minutes cannot and should not be a transcript of a board meeting, in a post-royal commission world they need to record not only the resolutions reached by the board, but also some detail on how those resolutions were reached.

Graham Bradley says board minutes need essential detail, not extensive detail. Cole Bennetts

Former Business Council of Australia president and prominent non-executive director Graham Bradley provided a good starting point for the basics of a good set of minutes in a discussion held by the AICD after the release of the joint statement.

“What I look for is a set of minutes that are clear and succinct, unambiguous, obviously accurate and factual, but also in plain English with as few acronyms as possible so that they are intelligible to a wider audience,” Bradley said in a webinar.

He also acknowledged that there had been some recent tweaks around what good minutes look like, wryly noting that where once minutes were seen as a “letter to an unknown judge”, they were now a “letter to an unknown royal commissioner”.

To this end, there did need to be more detail to show how resolutions were arrived at, noting where and why directors questioned management, sought clarification and asked for more information, he said.

Advertisement

“It’s advisable to state some of the main considerations that the board considered in coming to its decision in more detail than [previously] you might have – not excessive detail, only essential detail,” Bradley said.

“I think [minutes] need to be complete, but that doesn’t mean they need to be excessively long. They need to have only the essential details to support the decisions.”

The joint statement is specific that the votes of individual directors should not be recorded, except where there is an abstention or a dissent.

Bradley goes further, slapping directors who want to see their “name in the minutes to show you’re actually doing your job”.

“I think the problem with quoting an individual director by name is that the poor old minute-taker will never get it absolutely accurate and you’ll have a big debate about whether that was exactly what was said,” he said.

Bradley said another important change in the past decade had been the addition of action lists that come out of each meeting. These could then be assessed by directors at the start of the next meeting.

“That document can be more widely circulated to management as a checklist of what they need to do. Then there’s a running record of things that are to be done, and what’s happened to them.”

A fascinating question also addressed by the Governance Institute and the AICD is whether the legal privilege that attaches to confidential communications between lawyers and clients extends to board minutes. The message is that caution is needed.

“Privilege is not usually lost by the board receiving the advice,” the statement says. “However, it is important to exercise caution and judgment in determining the degree of detail of privileged information (if any) that is necessary to include in the minutes.”
description: The royal commission helped put the spotlight on what should and shouldn't be in board minutes.
